text.text: We did some research (er... like always?) and have come to the conclusion that swimming is good for the health: both physical and mental. Given the popularity of lidos and bathing spots in London, it's kinda obvious that we could do with a lot more outdoor spaces to get wet. But as someone wise once said, it is what it is. And this is what it is:

tip.text:
Built in 1938 with a refurb in 2005, this swimming spot is a 60 x 27 metre uncovered and unheated pool. It's got a stainless steel pool lining which creates a real nice reflective blue effect in the water and doesn't tend to get too busy unless it's one of those hot summer days. Inside the lido area is a cafe and plenty of space to lounge about in. Check the timings on the website as they are liable to change.

Oh and it costs £6 to enter.

text.text:
You can find this Grade II-listed Art Deco pool at the south-eastern tip of Hampstead Heath, full of sugared-up kids on a hot day and stern triathlon trainers on any other. Some cash was recently showered on it leaving it with a stainless steel liner that gives the water an entrancing, inviting shimmer. This is a big 'un: it measures 61m x 27m and is a little on the cold side but come on, you're a tough sort. 

Entry: £4-7

tip.text:
Known locally as Brixton’s Beach, this pool in Brockwell Park has an Olympic sized 50 metre pool surrounded by a beautiful Grade II listed Art Deco building with cafe. They also put on other events here such as film nights and furniture fairs which has made it a bit of a hub for the community.

Swim and go price is £5.95.

text.text:
The words Brixton and beach have become weirdly synonymous in recent times - so much so that it's hard to think of one without the other. But this is its original: a 50m pool that's also got that art deco, Grade-II listed thing going for it. This place is obscenely busy in summer but pick evenings and more temperate times and it's a lovely place for a dip. Notable mention for the cafe on site too. 

Entry: £4-6.10

tip.text:
Unless there's a heatwave, this one is probably best left to serious swimmers. Open since 1906, it's the largest swimming pool in the UK at a staggering 90 metres long - and you know what your mother told you about starting something you won't be able to finish. Notorious for its invigorating water and colourful changing room, this is only open to the public in the summer; winter swims require membership.

Opening times are subject to seasons so please check the website for details.

text.text:
Unless there's a heatwave, this one is probably best left to serious swimmers. Open since 1906, it's the largest swimming pool in the UK at a staggering 90 metres long - and you know what your mother told you about not starting something you won't be able to finish. Notorious for its invigorating water and colourful changing room, this is only open to the public in the summer; winter swims require membership.

Entry: £6-8

tip.text: After what feels like a horrible eternity, London Fields lido is back up and running. This is the rarest of gems in London: a heated 50m outdoor pool with decent facilities to boot where inconceivably spritely speedo-clad swimmers glide up and down the lanes without losing their breath. They have swimming lessons for children and adults, a sunbathing area, cafe and swimfit sessions too. It gets super busy here in the summer and is probably best avoided on hot days.

text.text:
Our love is large for London Fields Lido: a chlorine-laced symbol of Hackney's regeneration. The pool is 50m and, perhaps most importantly of all, heated all year round. That might mean it attracts the masses from surrounding parts in summer, but it also means evening dips in winter are pretty enjoyable too. The facilities here are also really very nice indeed. 

Entry: £5

tip.text:
After a big old refurb in 2013, this Olympic sized 50m pool is heated and has two big sun terraces for lounging, a cafe and gym on site.

Price for a dip is £6 on the door or £5 online so maybe book ahead to save yourself that nugget.

text.text:
Sure, Charlton isn't top of your list of places to visit but look - it has a lido! You've travelled a lot further for a lot worse. After a refurb in 2013, this 50m heated pool stepped its game up to become another people trap during the summer, but a solid place to stretch the limbs and get naked in front of total strangers nonetheless. 

Entry: £6

tip.text: Park Road Lido has been a Crouch End watering hole since 1926, but pools aren't one of those places where 'old school' is much of a selling point so you'll be glad to know they've had a recent refurb. The place is now a 50x23m heated outdoor pool - the largest in London according to them. As much as we love a splash about, we're equally into chilling in the sun and the grassy bank and sun loungers here are perfect for such frivolity.

text.text:
It's Crouch End. A recently renovated 50m lido. The water is heated. There's a sauna. It's open all year round. What else is there? Well the building is a bit dilapidated and the actual running of this place can be a bit of a shitshow, so you will want to avoid on busy days if at all possible.

Entry:  £4.60-5.70

tip.text: Frankly, we're not sure what you're doing way out here in Uxbridge. But it just so happens that a lido lives here, and it goes by the name of Hillingdon. It got a refurb back in 2010 and has been restored to its former 1930s glory: a 50m pool that's shaped like a 12 sided star. Important to note that the pool is only open in the summer - you can infer from that that it's not heated.

text.text:
Frankly, we're not sure what you'd be doing way out here in Uxbridge but it just so happens that a lido is here that goes by the name of Hillingdon. It got a refurb back in 2010 and has been restored to its former 1930s glory: a 50m pool that's uniquely shaped like a 12 sided star. Important to note that the pool is only open in the summer - you can infer from that that it's not heated.

Entry: £5-7

tip.text:
If you've ever found yourself in Hampstead Heath on a warm day, you'll know the bathing ponds attract people like nothing else. And there's a reason for that: it's a delightful place to get back to nature and cool off - and we really do mean cool off, the water here is goddamn cold.

Originally dammed off clay pits, there are three 3 swimming ponds: mixed, female and male which are surrounded by willow trees, woodland and cruisers (the male pond). Jump in, have a swim, then dry off on the grassy banks - if you can find a space.

text.text:
There's a reason that the bathing ponds in Hampstead attract people like nothing else: they're a delightful place to get back to nature and cool off - and we really do mean cool off. Formed from old clay pits, you've got a mixed, female and male pond here all surrounded by willow trees, woodland and potentially some speedo-clad cruisers (the male pond). 

Entry: £2

tip.text: People have been dipping their toes, feet and the rest in the Serpentine for over 100 years so we're not about to argue. It's 100m (!) of open water swimming that's pretty popular with serious swimmers who aren't into the whole chlorine thing. It's only open to us plebs from May to September, thereafter you have to be part of their club.

text.text:
People have been dipping their toes, feet and the rest in the Serpentine for over 100 years so we're not about to argue. It's 100m (!) of open water swimming that's pretty popular with serious swimmers who don't dig chlorine. It's only open to us plebs from May to September, thereafter you have to be part of their club.

Entry: £4.80

address.line1: London Royal Docks Open Water Swimming

tip.text: Before we go any further, know that you'll need a wetsuit to go swimming here. If that sounds alright with you then it's alright with us. It's your life after all. The Royal Docks is one of the most iconic places to do a bit of open water swimming, with different routes of 400m, 750m and 1500m to tackle. You need to book ahead here and get a NOWCA wristband before you get in that water, so check their website for the full details.

text.text:
Um so things have got kind of serious now - you'll need a wetsuit to go swimming here. If that sounds alright with you then it's alright with us. It's your life after all. The Royal Docks way out east is one of the most iconic places to do a bit of open water swimming, with different routes of 400m, 750m and 1500m to tackle. You need to book ahead here and get a NOWCA wristband before you get in that water, so check their website for the full details. 

Entry: £8

tip.text:
It might look like your run of the mill reservoir, but if you know the right time to go and the right things to wear, you might just swim in this reservoir. On Thursday evenings and Saturday and Sunday mornings they hold open water swimming sessions where a load of serious swimmers clad in wet suits do their thing. You need to do an induction here before taking part, so book on for that.

Also, you can also book on for introductory sailing lessons here if you want to get serious out on the water. The course duration is 2 days and the cost is a mean £165.

text.text:
It might look like your run of the mill reservoir, but if you know the right time to go and the right things to wear, you might just swim in that reservoir. On Thursday evenings and Saturday and Sunday mornings they hold open water swimming sessions where a load of serious swimmers clad in wet suits do their thing. You need to do an induction here (£15) before taking part, so book on for that. 

Entry: £5- £10 (non-members)
